sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Good morning, Europe. It's Thursday, the 20th of January.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Very warm welcome to the programme.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Let's begin by looking at our top stories.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: US President Joe Biden predicts Russia will move in on Ukraine, but he warns Vladimir Putin there will be a serious price to pay.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: In the UK, the Partygate scandal keeps the pressure on Boris Johnson as members of his own party call on him to resign.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: And tributes pour in to French actor Gaspard Ulliel after his untimely death at the age of just 37.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: US President Joe Biden says he believes Vladimir Putin will move in, but does not want a full-blown

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: war with Ukraine, adding that he will pay a serious and dear price if he does move forward with a military incursion.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: If they actually do what they're capable of doing with the force amassed on the border, it is going to be a disaster for Russia if they further invade Ukraine and that our allies and partners are ready to impose severe cost and significant harm on Russia and the Russian economy." Amid the soaring tensions, French President Emmanuel Macron called on the European Union to quickly draw up a new security plan and urged to have a frank dialogue with Russia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: These next weeks must lead to a European proposal to build a new security and stability pact.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: We must build it between Europeans, before we share it with our allies within NATO and then offer it up for negotiation with Russia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: His German counterpart Olaf Scholz said that after years of rising tensions, staying silent is not a sensible option.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: That is why we are talking to Moscow in a range of different formats about our commitment to Ukraine's territorial integrity and about a key principle of our common European peace order that borders must not be moved by force.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken has promised Ukraine more military aid in the face of aggressive plans by Russian President Vladimir Putin, whom he accused of refusing to de-escalate military tensions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Moscow said they will accept nothing less but watertight U.S. guarantees precluding NATO's expansion to Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken will be here in Berlin today to meet with his German counterpart, Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock, as well as the so-called transatlantic quad that also includes France and the UK.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Now, a key issue on the agenda, of course, will be Allies' readiness to impose potentially massive consequences and economic costs on Russia should there be any further aggression towards Ukraine. And this is where things get particularly uncomfortable for Berlin right now. So German Chancellor Olaf Scholz said earlier this week that everything will have to be discussed should there indeed be a military intervention in Ukraine. And that includes the recently completed Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline between Russia and Germany. And this pipeline has been a contentious issue since the get-go as critics including the US and Ukraine say it will make the EU too dependent on Russian energy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: So Berlin is under real intense pressure now to halt the final approval of the pipeline as part of these possible sanction efforts.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: At the same time, another option being explored is cutting off Russian banks from the SWIFT payment system, that huge global network used to wire sums of money between nearly all financial institutions. But Germany says it's keen to avoid sanctions that would make it difficult for Europe to pay for gas and oil imports from Russia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: So certainly some more tough talks on the table today.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Kate Brady, Euronews, Berlin.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: The Kremlin is closely watching the US Secretary of State Antony Blinken's visit to Europe.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: It started in Kyiv and will end in Geneva where Mr Blinken will meet with the Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Vladimir Putin's spokesman described Geneva talks as extremely important and stressed that Moscow was hoping to get the written answer to its security demands from the US in the coming days. Mr. Blinken said he won't be presenting any formal paper to Mr. Lavrov in Kiev. He stressed that Russia could take an aggressive action against Ukraine on very short notice. Russian top politicians replied saying once again that moscow was not planning to attack or invade ukraine deputies from the communist party the second biggest faction in the russian upper house of parliament after the united russia ruling party suggested that the chamber asks vladimir putin to recognize the self-proclaimed separatist republics on the east The Kremlin said it has not heard about this suggestion.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Nevertheless, this scenario is no doubt one of many discussed by various Russian analysts.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: one of many discussed by various Russian analysts. Both Moscow and Washington are not expecting any breakthroughs in Geneva. In the US, those talks are seen as an opportunity to test whether Moscow really wants negotiations. Russia says it wants to understand the same about the US, underlining that the time is running out.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Galina Polonskaya for Euronews.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Britain's Boris Johnson faced another grueling Prime Minister's questions on Wednesday

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: as he tried to defend his position and deflect calls for his resignation over the so-called Partygate scandal that has left him fighting for his political life. More of these calls are now coming from within his own Conservative Party and one of his own MPs has defected to the opposition Labour Party. In Parliament the Prime Minister was put under intense pressure again from Labour leader Keir Starmer who said Johnson was trying to defend the indefensible.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: It requires the Prime Minister to expect us to believe that whilst every other person who was invited on the 20th of May to the party was told it was a social occasion, he alone was told it was a work meeting. Central to the main line of defence for Boris Johnson over the party held on May 20th is that he didn't know it was a party.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: He also claims to have not been aware of any concerns his staff had over the holding of it, something that's been directly disputed by at least two people.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Keir Starmer pushed him to tell Parliament what he knew and where.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: I'm grateful to right honourable gentleman for repeating the question that he's already asked. We have answered, Mr Speaker, that it is for the inquiry to come forward with an explanation of what happened.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: And I'm afraid he simply must wait.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Our reporter, Tiger Enright, is following events in London.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Boris Johnson is waking up in Downing Street this morning, but he can't be certain of whether he will end the day or indeed the week in the British Prime Minister's residence.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Yesterday he said he would not resign, despite a growing number of his own party's members of parliament calling on him to do so, after a long-running scandal over parties thrown in Downing Street at the height of Covid lockdowns.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: One veteran Conservative MP, David Davis, told him, in the name of God, go.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And two-thirds of voters surveyed by YouGov also believe he should resign.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: But Johnson clearly hopes that he can find a way to cling on.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: He's been asking for patience to allow a senior civil servant, Sue Gray, to complete her investigation into the list of parties, including one in the Downing Street Garden, which Johnson attended.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: The invitation told guests they should bring their own alcohol, but the Prime Minister said he thought it was a work event.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: In the background, MPs who want him gone have been writing letters of no confidence to a Conservative Party committee, hoping to trigger a formal process to remove him.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: There needs to be 54 such letters to get the ball rolling, and while there's been plenty of speculation about how many have been received, it is a closely guarded secret.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And the timing of the process is important, because if MPs force a vote and Johnson wins, well then he's immune for the same process for 12 months.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: So it could happen this week or perhaps not. We simply don't know for sure.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Johnson hopes though that the swift lifting of COVID restrictions, which he announced yesterday, will give him some breathing space.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: But one thing that's certain is that Johnson is not sitting comfortably and confident of his future this morning.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Ty Ghenright, Euronews in London.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Queues are growing at German public testing centers where waiting times are often more than an hour.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: As the country reached 100,000 new daily COVID-19 infections for the first time, Health Minister Karl Lauterberg has reiterated his calls for a general vaccine mandate, which he says should come into force by May.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: It's a concern shared by the UK, where Health Secretary Sajid Javid insisted that the health crisis isn't over, despite the government announcing that it's lifting all pandemic restrictions from next week. We must learn to live with Covid in the same way that we've learned to live with flu. In Eastern Europe Covid cases are spiking with Romania one of the EU's least vaccinated countries suffering a second consecutive day of record new infections approaching last year's October figures.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: There are very few people at the vaccination centre. That probably has to do with the lack of a proper politics from the government. There's not enough mobilisation of the population.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: I'm not sure why there are so few people here, but these anti-vaccination influences probably all of these have an effect. Poland health workers say they are exhausted and overworked and are afraid polish hospitals are not prepared for another surge meanwhile health authorities predict the number of infections could double in the coming week.
